title: 'Back to the Future': What the movie got right, and wrong, about 2015

Join the Conversation To find out more about Facebook commenting please read the Conversation Guidelines and FAQs 'Back to the Future': What the movie got right, and wrong, about 2015 Steve Staeger predicts what we might see in the next 30 years. Steve Staeger and USA Today, news source 10:34 p.m. MDT October 21, 2015 Christopher Lloyd and Michael J. Fox in 'Back to the Future, Part II.' (Photo: Universal City Studios) CONNECT TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE 
USA TODAY - Great Scott! The future is here. 
The second installment of the Back To The Future trilogy finds Marty McFly, portrayed by Michael J. Fox, time-traveling to Oct. 21, 2015.Among his discoveries are hand-held computers, video chatting, Major League Baseball in Miami, and a preponderance of cameras. 
But what is life really like 30 years after the movie? 
For all the guesses the movie got wrong, did it get anything right? 
Many still believe we'll see flying cars 30 years from now. Jonathan Moyer, the acting director of the Pardee Center for International Futures says not so much. 
"I think that's been a prediction that's been wrong pretty consistently across time and I think it gets down to the physics," he said. 
Moyer said more driverless or driver-assisted cars could be on the roads in 30 years. 
Some predict technology will keep getting smaller, but Moyer said that may be tough to do. 
"We're really not that great at making batteries as efficient but increasingly smaller as we are at making computers as powerful but increasingly smaller." 
For what it's worth, Nike is bringing the future to us with some self-tying shoes. 
USA TODAY was in the future. It still exists
